title: 111_hr2198
content: Recovery period for depreciation of certain systems installed in nonresidential and residential rental buildings. The 20-year recovery period for highly efficient HVAC&R equipment is amended to include initial clearing and grading land improvements for electric utility transmission and distribution plants, as well as properties part of heating, ventilation, air conditioning, or commercial refrigeration systems exceeding by at least 10 percent the applicable minimum. The 20-year recovery period for highly efficient HVAC&R equipment is amended to include properties part of heating, ventilation, air conditioning, or commercial refrigeration systems exceeding by at least 10 percent the applicable minimum performance standard under energy conservation acts. The 25-year recovery period for certain properties, including nonresidential real property or residential rental property with original use starting with the taxpayer and placed in service before January 1, 2013, is defined as '25-year property' under Section 168(e)(3) of the Code. The 25-year recovery period for certain properties, including nonresidential real property or residential rental property with original use starting with the taxpayer and placed in service before January 1, 2013, is defined as '25-year property' under Section 168(e)(3) of the Code. Amendments are made to the table in section 168(c) to include this definition. Amendments were made to the table in section 168(c) by inserting a new item after the 20-year property definition. Amendments were made to the table in section 467(e)(3)(A) by inserting a new item after the residential rental property and nonresidential real property definitions. Amendments were made to section 168 of the Code, requiring the use of the straight-line method for certain properties. The table in section 168(g)(3)(B) was also updated to reflect these changes. The amendments made to section 168 of the Code require the use of the straight-line method for certain properties placed in service after December 31, 2008.
